Deflation ONLY becomes a system wide liquidity crisis (net wide collapse of the 'currency supply') under a fractional reserve monetry system and an interest rate requirement on base currency.

Deflation increases the purchasing power of 'currency' and when one area of the market collapse (due to real demand shortages or over supply) the increase in monetery value causes projects to become economically viable in another area of the economy.

Under our currency system, when deflation hits (due to the credit crunch or debt saturation - disposable income / credit reaches its limit), currency supporting the existing currency supply defaults and we get the system wide collapse of the currency supply effecting all markets (off setting any positive effects of each unit of currency regaining purchasing power in the short run...).

Deflation and inflation based or real market driven demand and supply are both good and act as a balancing sustainable force if sound money is enforced. This allows for under and over supplied segments of a 'free market, price discovery, non manipulated' economey to grow and contract with out system wide collapse and the free market instantly determines were Groth and contraction is required.

Artificial continued inflation driven on the currency supply side that stimulates fully satisfied real market demand and props up any over supplied failing market segments and requires continued growth of the currency supply via credit creation to prevent net wide defaults will result in system wide collapse during deflationary episodes EVERY TIME - proven by every Fiat currency every created.

The response of every central bank is to increase the currency supply until debt to desposable income of the system does not allow for any more credit to be absorbed to continue growing the currency supply.

Why do we get debt saturated? = Triffins Delima (applies to any Fiat fractional reserve, intrest Lauren base currency system - not just global reserve currency).

The key of sound money requires the production of the the 'Money Supply' to come under the same economic fundamentals that any venture requires to be profitable - i.e. the production of new money 'net wise' has to be equal to the opertunity cost to create it (i.e. typing any number digits onto a computer does not represent the opertunity cost to create that new currency, it just stole the purchasing power from every other unit of that denominated currency in existence as it was not balanced out by the value created back into the system on the goods and services side to creat the new currency).

My grandma and grandpa both were born in 1929 before the stock market crash and lived through the Depression. One day, I was eating an oatmeal cookie and I did not like it after one bite. I tossed the cookie in the trash can and my grandma walked over and reached into the trash can, picked it up, examined it, then ate it. I told her that we had plenty and she didn't have to eat from the trash. Her reply was surprising to me, "You don't waste food. You never grew up during the Depression." It was shocking to hear that as a kid. Especially a history nerd. I never truly understood what it was like for people during the Great Depression until that day when she told me about that. Years later, my father told me that his father, my grandpa, would have one pack of gum of year because he used to save chewed up gum for weeks because it was all he could get during the Depression. And my dad also told me that when he was a kid, his parents would tell him about how they only had one pair of shoes a year. And this lasted from the Depression until the end of WWII. My grandparents were very simple people. Very grateful for having what they had. I believe a lot of that stemmed from being children during the Depression.

The Great Depression lasted 10 years. And the New Deal which raised taxes even more and increased regulations caused the economy to be even worse. The trough of the Great Depression occurred in 1937, four years after the start of the New Deal. Deflation is bad in that people get laid off.  Inflation is bad, because money becomes worth less.  Both lead to the same thing, but with different looks.  In an inflation spiral you end up like Germany after WW1 with people rolling wheelbarrows full of money to buy a little food.  In a deflation spiral you end up with almost no money period.  I would guess the difference comes with the speed it would take effect, but ultimately they end in a depression.

The problem with this analysis is that employment is always a lagging indicator of economic growth or decline.  Bringing on new employees or laying them off is always a reaction to changing economic conditions, not a cause of it.  Using employment to indicate the beginning of a depression is like using flooding to mark the beginning of a storm.

When I was just starting out in video production I learned to avoid "jump cuts" at all costs.  This "rule" has, unfortunately, been abandoned, particularly here on YouTube.  I love the subject matter addressed in these videos....Unfortunately, I cannot bear to watch them.  Removing all of the natural pauses from the narrator's speech turns them into "motormouth" screeds.  No time for reflection, analysis, or even delight when a new bit of information is learned.  It's just a string of words lacking flow and connection.  I hope that someone will produce videos on these subjects that use air-breathing narrators who actually inhale occasionally.  If you want to do a short and meaningful video, careful editing of your narration would give you shorter videos with much better content.  Cramming all of the vowels you can into each minute does not help the audience to hear, consider, and appreciate the ideas.  Try it.

The farm crisis in the 1920s was based in rapidly changing technology. Switching from horses to the internal combustion engine drastically reduced the market for horse fodder, and in the late 19th century, horses ate far more than people did. Crop prices collapsed, farms went bankrupt, and hundreds of thousands of farmers lost their homes. The Dust Bowl made things worse, but the disaster was already in progress. The Great Migration was not made up of city dwellers, it was made up of farmers and agricultural workers who were displaced by the shift from horse drawn carriages to automobiles.

The Great Depression
INTRODUCTION
The Great Depression of the 1930s has influenced the study of macroeconomics more than any other event in history. It was so significant, that it led to the creation of a new branch of economics-Macroeconomics. This event is considered to have been the reason for founding of macroeconomics as a separate branch of economics.
The general public mostly associated the Great Depression with the crash in the stock market that occurred in October, 1929. Indeed, stock prices fell dramatically on the day of the crash and the trend continued for several years post that. However, the Great Depression was not just a crash in the financial markets; it was a much bigger event. The crash was a co-symptom of a variety of underlying issues rather than the cause of the depression.
The Great Depression is important to understand due to: 1. Its magnitude as a social phenomenon; 2. Its impact on how the world views Macro Economics and 3. It's importance in changing the role of federal government in the American economy. In the words of Milton Friedman and Anna Schwartz, from their Monetary History of the United States, "The contraction from 1929 to 1933 was by far the most severe business-cycle contraction during the near-century of U.S. history we cover [1867-1960] and it may well have been the most severe in the whole of U.S. history. Though sharper and more prolonged in the United States than in most other countries, it was worldwide in scope and ranks as the most severe and widely diffused international contraction of modern times. U.S. net national product in current prices fell by more than one-half from 1929 to 1933; net national product in constant prices, by more than one-third; implicit prices [a broad index of prices across the economy], by more than one-quarter; and monthly wholesale prices, by more than one-third." From a social and macroeconomic perspective, the most commonly cited business cycles indicator, the unemployment rate, rose from 3.2% of the labour force in 1929 to 24.9% in 1933. Unemployment fell to 14.3% in 1937, but then increased again to 19.0% in 1938 and was still 9.9% in 1941 before the boost received from military recruitment associated with World War II brought it down to 1.9% in 1943. Real gross national product (output of goods and services) per person only recovered to its original levels of 1929 after 1940. As the above quote suggests, prices kept falling steadily through 1930s as well. Table 1 summarizes some major macroeconomic statistics for the period 1925 to 1940.
The Great Depression altered the role of the federal government in America’s economy. Pre
Depression, federal government spending accounted for less than 3 percent of GDP while post the event by 1939, federal outlays exceeded 10 percent of GDP. The Great Depression was also the reason for the formation of Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC), stringent regulations of securities markets, the birth of the Social Security System and the first national minimum wage.

CAUSES OF THE GREAT DEPRESSION
Economists disagree on what caused The Great Depression- which is why they continue to study it. While many theories have been proposed over the years, there remains no single theory which is universally agreed upon.
The 1929 stock market crash is often the first thing that comes to mind when people think of the Great Depression. The crash wiped out considerable wealth, but perhaps what was more important was that it sparked doubts about the health of the economy. This then led consumers and firms to pull back on their spending, especially on big-ticket items like cars and appliances. However, as distressing as the crash was, it was not the sole reason for the Great Depression.
Some economists cite the protectionist trade policies and the collapse of international trade as the reason for the Great Depression. The Smoot-Hawley tariff of 1930 artificially increased the cost of imported goods and led to retaliatory actions by major trading partners of the United States. This being said, the Great Depression was a worldwide phenomenon, the collapse of international trade was greater than the decline of world output of goods and services. Still, similar to the stock market crash, protectionist trade policies alone did not lead to the Great Depression.
Other experts offer different explanations for the Great Depression. Some historians have called the depression an unavoidable failure of capitalism. Others blame the Depression on the “excesses” of the 1920s: excessive building, excessive production of commodities, excessive spending, excessive financial speculation and excessively skewed distribution of income and wealth. None of these explanations have held up well over time.
On the contrary, one explanation that has stood the test of time focuses on the downfall of the U.S. banking system, resulting in the contraction of the nation’s money supply. As money stock fell, consumer spending on goods and services declined, which in turn pushed firms to cut prices, reduce output and lay off workers. The consequent decline in income made it more difficult for borrowers to repay loans. This caused defaults and bankruptcies to soar, creating a vicious spiral in which banks failed, leading to further contraction in the money stock, and continued decline of output, prices and employment.
When we think about the stock market crash in parallel to this, the effect is compounded. Stocks lost about three-quarters of their value between October 1929 and 1933. At that time, it was common for investors to borrow money from banks to purchase stocks "on margin" with the value of the stocks as collateral on such loans (Such margin loans are now much more carefully regulated). A sudden collapse in stock prices reduced the value of the collateral, triggering banks to make margin calls where investors were asked to either repay their loans or provide additional collateral. In order to obtain enough liquidity to meet margin requirements, investors attempted to sell their stock, which drove stock prices lower more rapidly in a self-reinforcing spiral. Since many customers were not able to get enough liquidity to make their margin calls, defaults on bank loans soared, leading to a loss in confidence in the banking system.
As bank deposits were not insured at that time, the depositor who held an account in a bank that defaulted would not receive any compensation for his loss. This meant that depositors who were able to withdraw their money before it actually closed would be paid in full, while others would get their money back only in part and only after the bank's remaining assets would be sold. This created a race to be first to the withdrawal window, starting what is called a "run on the bank".
However, banks keep only a small fraction of depositors' money in the form of liquid reserves (vault cash and readily available deposits at the Federal Reserve Banks), while the rest is lent to customers to earn interest or used to purchase interest bearing securities. A run on the bank can use up a bank's reserves swiftly, forcing it to either (1) sell some of its loans and/or securities immediately for cash, (2) borrow cash , perhaps from the Federal Reserve, or (3) close down, at least temporarily. The securities (and even loans) of a bank are quite liquid (commonly traded, so it is easy to find a willing buyer) during normal times, but during a crisis there are far more sellers in the market than buyers. If a bank is forced to sell into a distressed market, they may get very low prices for the assets they sell. If they sell assets at a loss, the bank’s situation worsens and may push it over the edge into insolvency - the bank's liabilities exceed its assets causing it to fail.
When the Federal Reserve System was founded in 1913, its primary mission was to provide an "elastic currency" by acting as a "lender of last resort" for banks, lending through the "discount window" by purchasing their loans and securities for cash when the banks faced runs and needed liquidity. However, during the Great Depression the stringent rules put in place by the Fed on the securities it would accept as collateral disabled banks from avoiding a bank run. Between 1929 and 1933, bank failures became so common that the number of commercial banks operating in the United States fell by over one-third.
RECOVERY FROM THE DEPRESSION
The monetary damage experienced during the Great Depression finally ended when President Franklin D. Roosevelt declared a national bank holiday just one day after he took office in March 1933. Roosevelt ordered all banks to close, including the Federal Reserve banks. He permitted them to reopen only after they received a government license. Meanwhile, the federal government set up a temporary system of federal deposit insurance and a year later followed up by creating the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and a permanent deposit insurance system.
Roosevelt’s policies reinstated confidence in the banking system, and money poured back into the banks. Money supply began to increase, which in turn increased spending, production as well as leading to a rise in prices. Economic recovery was slow, but the bottom had been reached and good times were in sight.
History books credit Roosevelt’s New Deal as the beginning of the economic recovery from the Great Depression. Under the New Deal, the government put in place many programs of relief and recovery that employed thousands of people and made direct cash grants or loans to individuals, firms and local governments. However, in the first few years of the New Deal, federal government spending did not increase significantly.

This is such an inaccurate representation of what actually occurred.
Most notably is the representation of the Smoot-Hawley Tariff. The way it is presented seems to say that the tariff was enacted before Hoover came to power and he did little in response.
In reality, Hoover was the president that signed the bill into law.
------
The notion that the US keeping the gold standard while European nations dissolved does not thereby mean economic calamity took place in response. The fact that the US didn't lose the gold standard like other nations did is a main reason why global trade is conducted in US dollars today rather than another currency. While the value of the US dollar would remain stable, foreign nations that pursued inflationary economic policy would see the value of their currency change wildly since their currency was not representative of any tangible thing.
-------
The notion that Hoover did nothing to avert the depression is simply wrong. He fought companies who were trying to marginally reduce wages in response to the economic situation. Rather than letting the market balance itself, he insisted upon intervening to maintain wages. He forced companies to pay higher wages which made it almost impossible for the US private sector to sell their goods. The prices for US goods went up in response which made it that much harder for American business to compete on the global scale. Yes, American worker wages remained steady. However, once American business' were bankrupted the former wage earners had no job at all.
------
The problem isn't that Hoover didn't try to have enough influence. The problem is that he tried far to hard to influence the situation. He knew that private business' were the best way out of the situation. Rather than leaving them to their own devices he continually meddled in their operations. Had he gotten the hell out of the way the US would have been able to rebound from recession just as it had in the past. Yes, the rebound would not be instantaneous. However, it would be steady and have a great deal of longevity.
------
The Revenue Act of 1932 did not 'arguably' make the situation worse. IT DID make the situation worse. It jacked up taxes and most notably the top rate went from 25% to 63%. New investments in industry that would be necessary to work out of the recession were stopped cold in their tracks. The rich that otherwise would have built new business' and developed new technologies said to hell with it since their profit motive had been taken away.
------
Yes, by 1932 the depression was already under way. The tariff Hoover had placed had decimated nearly every sector of American industry. Once the industries fell the rest of the economic sectors collapsed as well.
------
Roosevelt then rode into town and spent an extreme amount on public works projects, but also vast welfare systems and brand new concept of the military industrial concept. All three of these areas have grown far out of proportion and are currently crippling the US economy with the resulting exponential growth in the national debt.

wait a sec, two things... first: did you say that essentially if the federal reserve had bailed out the banks; and second if the Hoover administration had conducted and economic stimulus package consisting of public works projects the great depression wouldn't have gone on for the decade it did and wouldn't have been that bad? If this is indeed your claim I will have to respectfully disagree as the basic premise behind this is laughable. first off the Hoover administration did do an economic stimulus package in which, among a large number of other things, the Hoover dam was built. The major misconception about Hoover comes from an ideological stance based on his political party, basically most people think that because he was a Republican he was not into public economic spending and the expansion of government. This thinking however is false, Hoover adamantly believed that the only way out of the great depression was  engineering the economy through government spending, which was a horrible idea keeping us in the depression. As for the federal reserve bailing out banks, we have the perfect example of why that is a horrible idea in 2008 when then President Obama bailed out the banks, citing that they are to big to fail, which is a fallacy. Nothing is to big to fail, if the banks had failed smaller banks would have purchased all of the toxic assets creating a decent number of smaller banks instead of a handful of obscenely large banks. Yes all of Obama's banking friends would have had to sulk back to the Hamptions with their tails between their legs but the banking industry wouldn't have taken the huge hit on trust it took and sound investments would have helped the economy. The only thing that would have ended the great depression would have been the government to leave it alone and let the free market fix and reregulate itself. What people who argue that the New Deal was inherently bad for the US is that, at the point in time the Great Depression was happening, the general populace had lost faith in the free market system and the ideas associated with it. When you don't trust the free market to give you a fair chance, as many people felt during this time (and, ironically, now), you are much less willing to reengage in the market and much less willing to support Laissez-Faire style policies. The New Deal did at that time what the free market alone could not: give people hope for a better future.

Perhaps that is the most important thing to look at regarding the Great Depression.

A 'banking crisis' happened around 1907 too, but it was over in two months when JP Morgan lent banks his money, knowing that he would get it back once the crisis was over. Then came the Federal Reserve in 1913, which fucked up everything by dumping money into the economy without any actual creation of value, thus making credit artificially low and sending false price signals to businessmen, who assumed that the economy was showing real growth. This is what led to the Roaring '20s, and PRECISELY what created the inevitable bust. Nobody, save a few economists like Mises saw it coming. It was basically a confirmation of the Austrian Business Cycle theory and a damning indictment of Central Planning.
The bust needn't have led to the Depression, but the Government being oh so wise decided to increase spending and go into massive deficits to fund it, and doubled income tax, reduced tax benefits, and ignored the gold standard, which led to Capital Flight, hence crushing the once free market.

One quibble: I think the U.S. government began to imagine a larger role for itself after the 1905 ('03? '01?) earthquake in California that led, eventually, to FEMA. Or Teddy Roosevelt's national parks program. Or conceivably earlier; if he'd had the resources it's arguable that Lincoln would have expanded government's role in the economy as far as he could. And there were certainly large problems that could have been solved by intense government intervention before the Great Depression. So it's not that the government hadn't done much before or imagined itself with slim role in American society, but that perhaps there just hadn't been the intersection of a Big Gov't-sized problem with a Big Gov't-sized imagination and Big Gov't resources before.

To show how deep the misconceptions go, may I addend this bit of our favorite source, Wikipedia, on the topic?
Here's what the Wiki says--

"Merchants of death was an epithet used in the U.S. in the 1930s to attack industries and banks that supplied and funded World War I (then called the Great War). The term originated as the title of a book by H. C. Engelbrecht and F. C. Hanighen, Merchants of Death (1934), an exposé. The term was popular in antiwar circles of both the left and the right, and was used extensively regarding the Senate hearings in 1936 by the Nye Committee.[1]

The Senate hearing examined how much influence the manufacturers of armaments had in the American decision to enter WWI. 93 hearings were held, over 200 witnesses were called, and little hard evidence was found. The Nye Committee came to an end when Chairman Nye accused President Woodrow Wilson of withholding information from Congress when he chose to enter WWI. The failure of the committee to find a conspiracy did not change public prejudice again the manufactures of armaments, thus the popular name "Merchants of death". See the United States Senate, Senate History page."

The Gold Standard wasn't really a limiting factor at this point. Only 40% of the gold supply had currency in circulation backed by it, so the government could have printed a lot more money before hitting the limit. The real problem was that the government didn't help the banks suffering from runs (this being pre-FDIC) and the knock-on effects that followed. Then Britain abandoning the gold standard meant we had no common currency and that just aggravated things.

But the existence of the gold standard was not (yet) a cause, and its repeal was not a cure for the Great Depression.

Hoover didn't hold an official political position before becoming president, but he was involved in the public sector and had some experience in large scale organization. Hoover was is in charge of the Food and Drug Administration under Wilson's administration in WWI, which perhaps exemplifies Hoover's "volunteerism" approach to fixing the Great Depression. Also, it is a mistake to classify the lack of action by Hoover as ineptitude. From the eyes of someone in 2016, it may appear as such, but the role of government was extremely different in the 20s, even aside from the "business doctrine." To FDR's credit, it would take an incredible executive to reshape the role of the Federal government, and even with federal expansion, the GD didn't truly end until WWII.

Hello! I use your videos with my classes routinely. I finally disagree with you! Here goes:

I think a problem with your analysis begins with the claim that the stock market crash did not cause the Great Depression, but earlier and less proximate causes did, along with later events which were directly caused by the market crash.

If Andrew Jackson is to blame, certainly Black Tuesday is as well. It's not just correlation as you stated.

The glaring mistake is placing blame on the bank failures that followed the crash, when those failures were directly caused by the inability of banks to recover loans they had made to brokerage houses... because the market crashed. Also, banks were unable to pay out to depositors who ran on the banks in 1930...but depositors ran on the banks... because of the crash.

Simply put... we would not have seen those bank failures without the market crash. And indeed, where you are correct, we would not have seen the market crash if we had not engaged in the fundamental cause: rampant speculation leading to exponential over-valuation of corporations and their stock shares.

also you should ask why credit suddenly became so cheap in the 1920s - unlike any other period in history before. it seems too coincidental that the fed had just been created and been keeping the discount rate lower than it otherwise would have been.

the fed even appears to say this on their own website https://www.minneapolisfed.org/publications/the-region/a-history-of-the-federal-reserve-volume-1-19131951

"Meltzer reports that commercial banks borrowed heavily at the Fed's discount window from 1919 to the end of 1921. The Fed did not then discourage borrowing, and eligible collateral was abundant. In fact, aggregate borrowing actually exceeded total bank reserves most of the time. That is, the banking system then financed all of its reserves plus a portion of currency in circulation by borrowing from the Fed! Collateralized discount window loans were essentially riskless, and other money market rates floated relative to the discount rate at spreads commensurate with their riskiness. In other words, the Fed's discount rate put a ceiling on relatively riskless money market rates and, thereby, held riskier loan rates down as well."

Government intervention created the depression. It's actually not a mystery among economist at all, just an unpopular opinion in the political spectrum. 

The federal reserve bank(one of the worst institutions in the govt), inflated the money supply in the 1920's causing artificially low interest rates and duping businesses into borrowing money for large investments/developments. When they finally realized how dangerous the inflation was becoming, they basically panicked and cut the money supply by %40. That was an incredible slash for the entire american economy. PREDICTABLY, the interest rates shot up very high. And when you take out a loan for a couple million dollars... interest points mean a lot, I think we all know that. It can do a lot of damage to your business, especially in an expansion phase. This caused stocks to be crippled and wiped out many businesses, especially the small start ups.

Furthermore, both Hoover and FDR severely harmed the economy with all of their "relief" schemes. The depression realistically could have been over within a couple years, but festering the wounds kept the US economy bleeding for a whole decade. Its sad that, despite a very insightful analysis of what exactly happened, the consensus is "we are not exactly sure" or "capitalism collapsed".

If you would like to get a better sense of the total damage caused by federal monetary policy, I recommend "Great Myths of the Great Depression" an academic essay by Lawrence Reed

The 1920-21 recession/depression started out much more severe than the initial downtown in 1929-30. Deflation reached much higher levels in that earlier recession than during the GD, the stock market collapsed, and unemployment peaked into the teens. The government did NOTHING to "fix" the economy yet it had fully recovered by 1922. This was also the normal course for how recessions proceeded through the 19th century as well - where the government did NOTHING to "help" even during all out financial collapses yet the economy fully recovered within 2 or 3 years. That needs to be explained.

Answer: The early stages of the GD was the FIRST TIME that government had tried to "fix" the economy in the way that it did through the 1930s (by spending, regulating, price fixing, tariffs, and loose monetary policy) by the Fed, Hoover, and FDR.

I really enjoy Crash Course and and several other of your shows and I honestly love your views on some some subjects but I'll humbly disagree here as you only cover the facts of the great depression from a Keynesian (I know he didn't affect economic policy until the late 30's but his types of theories and view of history are what we're talking about here, not his policy) prospective. You could blame the start of the great depression on the failure of banks but more importantly - why did they start failing? The truth is the deflationary forces and the bank failures were caused by bad debt. You briefly touched on this but many loans for new items and new industry were created and spent as new money using the new "fractional reserve banking system". The bank failures happened because the banks made loans that people could never pay back. The natural result of these loans failing and the debt (another word for money in this case) disappearing from the economic system was deflation. To paraphrase Hayek, Malinvestment was the problem. The additional printing of money and cheap loans by the Federal Reserve does nothing to help the poor but increases the wealth gap. This'll be a little more complicated so bear with me. When the Fed infuses money into the economy they do so mainly by creating extremely low interest rate loans and encouraging lending (see, debt is money). This type of "soft landing" (the phrase most often used by Keynesians) to avoid deflation hands out cheap money to those who can borrow at the cost of inflation. In other words, those who already have assets can expand their existing assets by using market derivative or margin investments at the low point of the economy. This also created the seven year debt cycle as all loans or "debt money" are just borrowing against future income. In order for expansion there always has to be a deleveraging period where debt is destroyed for the creation of more debt. I'll avoid writing an entire book here but please understand the federal government cannot solve all problems and did nothing to help during the great depression. They made things much worse by prolonging the deleveraging period and creating future deleveraging periods in the debt cycle.

Some of his videos are great but he could not be more off base in this one. Prior to the Federal Reserve there were several periods of deflation that were actually a huge plus to the economy (usually in deflationary periods consumption, in real terms, would go up since falling prices meant the dollar went further - basically it should feel like everything is on sale). One of his main problems is in examining the depression overly from the bust side (a common practice even today).  The reality is that with a central bank you have artificial booms created by fiat creation of capital.  During the periods of boom you have malinvestment... meaning the market is being triggered with low interest rates to start long term projects (in a free market this would mean that peoples preferences are switching to saving or delaying consumption and thus there are freed up resources that can be used to complete long term projects).  Unfortunately at the same time consumer credit is doing the opposite of what needs to happen in order for the long term projects to succeed (ie. both longer term projects and shorter term consumption-oriented projects are scrambling for the same finite resources AND consumers are falling deeper into debt making it unlikely that they will be able to afford all the long term projects spurred on by the low interest rates).

I will say he does try and  give an even viewpoint but I think he just doesn't understand free market economics. The government has been massively intervening in the economy since the creation of the Federal Reserve in 1914... he is right that the depression started because of lack of capital but that is the nature of a central bank - it floods the market (or an industry - as in the tech boom of the 90's) and cuts it off when it sees fit and crashes everything... insiders that know what is coming (cough: Goldman Sachs) make billions off of this.

Two more things he gets way off:

1) Herbert Hoover WAS A LEFTIST! The previous too presidents were on the right (Calvin Coolidge and Harding who both had to live with the Federal Reserve but Harding pushed for DEFLATION which actually helped to end the recession of 1920 and kept it from becoming a depression). Hoover was trying to control the economy whereas his two predecessors did what they could to stay out of the way.

2) YOU CAN NOT BLAME ANDREW JACKSON!!!! Besides the fact that he hadn't been president for almost a century, if the world would have stuck with his plan to NOT have a central bank then there would never have been such an unstable boom which would NEVER have occurred without the Fed.  Of course the boom was not sustainable and the correction was VERY PAINFUL!

THOUGHTS ON THE CAUSES OF THE PRESENT DISCONTENTS - William Leggett, Democratick Editorials: Essays in Jacksonian Political Economy [1834]

Writes William Leggett

What has been, what ever must be, the consequence of such a sudden and prodigious inflation of the currency? Business stimulated to the most unhealthy activity; a vast amount of over production in the mechanick arts; a vast amount of speculation in property of every kind and name, at fictitious values; and finally, a vast and terrifick crash, when the treacherous and unsubstantial basis crumbles beneath the stupendous fabrick of credit, and the structure falls to the ground, burying in its ruins thousands who exulted in the fancied security of their elevation. Men, now-a-days, go to bed deeming themselves rich, and wake in the morning to find themselves stripped of even the little they really had. They count, deluded creatures! on the continued liberality of the banks, whose persuasive entreaties seduced them into the slippery paths of speculation. But they have now to learn that the banks cannot help them if they would, and would not if they could. They were free enough to lend their aid when assistance was not needed; but now, when it is indispensable to carry out the projects which would not have been undertaken but for the temptations they held forth, no further resources can be supplied. The banks must take care of themselves. “Charity begins at home.” The course of trade is turning against the country. We have purchased more commodities abroad than our products will pay for, and the balance will soon be called for in specie. The banks, which lately vied with one another in effusing their notes, are now as eager competitors in withdrawing them from circulation, and preparing for the anticipated shock. They have no time to listen to the prayers of the deluded men whom their deceitful lures seduced so far upon the treacherous sea of credit. They cast them adrift without remorse and leave them to encounter, unaided and unprepared, the fury of the gathering tempest. Or should, perchance, some tender hearted moneychanger relent, and consent to tow a few victims into harbour, is it unreasonable that he should charge wrecker’s fees for the service—half the cargo and twenty per cent commissions on the remainder? The cashiers of some of our banks can tell you that these are but the usual rates.

We should have responded like we did in the sharp contraction of the early 1920s: cut taxes, slashed spending, ran surpluses, and raised interest rates. It seems you have a few inaccurate ideas about GDP and what it is suppose to measure. GDP is measures the dollar value of all final goods and services produced by a nation's economy. It is not a measure of wealth or value. If I as an individual go out and buy a car, the dollar value of the car is added to GDP for the year I bought it. It does not matter whether I paid the full amount all at once, take out a loan to pay for it, because regardless the car is a final good produced by the economy.

One man's income is another man's spending. In an economy, the two must be equal. But people don't spend all that they make.
